GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Ocular Dryness
A subjective sensation of dryness, lack of lubrication, or grittiness in the eyes.
Foreign Body Sensation
The patient reports discomfort as if there is sand or a foreign object scratching inside the eye.
Burning or Stinging Sensation
A burning or stinging pain caused by ocular surface irritation.
Photophobia
Discomfort or worsening of eye pain induced by light stimulation.
Fluctuating Vision
Vision that noticeably improves and worsens throughout the day or after eye use.
Reduced Tear Film Break-Up Time
Fluorescein test shows decreased tear film stability, suggestive of dry eye.
Sudden Increase in Floaters
Appearance or significant increase of floating dark spots in a short period.
Photopsia / Flashes
Sensation of lightning-like flashes in the field of vision, often related to vitreous traction.
Curtain-like Shadow in Vision
A dark shadow advancing from the top, bottom, or side towards the center of the visual field.
Acute Decrease in Visual Acuity
A significant reduction in the level of vision over a short period.
Peripheral Field Defect
Visual field testing indicates decreased or absent sensitivity in the peripheral range.
Retinal Break/Detachment Observed
Direct observation of a retinal tear or elevation during fundus examination.
Eye Pain
Persistent pain or aching discomfort in the eye.
Ciliary Flush / Red Eye
A ring of purplish-red congestion around the cornea, indicative of anterior segment inflammation.
Blurred Vision
Lack of sharpness in both distance and near vision, which may worsen with fatigue.
Consensual Photophobia
Pain or increased photophobia in the affected eye when the healthy eye is illuminated.
Anterior Chamber Cells/Flare Positive
Slit-lamp examination reveals floating inflammatory cells and protein exudation.
Painless Blurring of Vision
Slowly progressive blurring of vision without associated pain.
Glare / Night Halos
Experience of dazzling light and rings around bright lights or at night.
Decreased Contrast Sensitivity
Reduced ability to distinguish between an object and its background in grayscale.
Myopic Shift
A shift in refractive status towards myopia, resulting in clearer near vision.
Monocular Diplopia
Double vision persists after covering the other eye, often associated with lens opacities.
Lens Opacity Observed
Direct observation of cortical, nuclear, or posterior capsular opacities of the lens via slit-lamp.
Central Vision Loss
Reduced visual acuity predominantly affecting the central fixation area.
Metamorphopsia
Straight lines appear bent or distorted, often indicating macular involvement.
Straight Lines Appear Wavy
Distortion of lines observed during an Amsler grid test.
Central Scotoma
A blind spot or area of reduced vision in the central visual field.
Difficulty Reading
Requires brighter light or larger print for near reading.
Macular Neovascularization/Leakage
Imaging studies reveal macular edema, leakage, or neovascularization.
Eyelid Pain/Tenderness
Significant pain upon touching the eyelid margin, usually due to local inflammation.
Localized Eyelid Nodule
A red, swollen, and firm lump on the eyelid margin, which may gradually suppurate.
Orbital Cellulitis
Infection of the soft tissues within the orbit, often accompanied by swelling, tenderness, and fever.
Eyelid Erythema
Localized flushing of the skin, indicating an inflammatory response.
Tearing
Increased tear secretion or reflex tearing.
Purulent Pustule on Eyelid Margin
A yellowish-white pus point visible at the base of the eyelashes or the orifice of a meibomian gland.
Fluctuating Floaters
The number or shape of floaters changes over time or with blood glucose fluctuations.
Poor Night Vision
Difficulty seeing in low-light conditions, with loss of detail.
Reduced Color Vision
Weakened ability to discriminate colors or a sense of faded color.
Glucose-Related Vision Fluctuation
Vision fluctuates with changes in blood glucose levels.
Diabetic Retinopathy Signs Confirmed
Fundus or imaging shows microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, or neovascularization.
Epiphora (Tearing)
Tears overflowing the eyelid margin, often due to corneal irritation or poor drainage.
Vitreous Opacity
Cloudiness in the vitreous humor, potentially affecting vision, common in the elderly or patients with eye diseases.
Vitreous Hemorrhage
Bleeding into the vitreous humor, which can be caused by retinal tears, diabetic retinopathy, or trauma, presenting as decreased vision, floaters, or visual field defects.
Retinal Tear
A partial-thickness break in the retina that can lead to retinal detachment; symptoms include flashes, floaters, and visual field defects, requiring prompt treatment.
Corneal Ulcer
A defect in the corneal epithelium or stroma, potentially caused by infection, trauma, or dry eye, presenting with pain, redness, tearing, and decreased vision.
Subconjunctival Hemorrhage
Bleeding from a ruptured blood vessel under the conjunctiva, typically appearing as a red spot or large patch on the white of the eye, usually painless.
Ptosis / Eyelid Drooping
Abnormally low position of the upper eyelid, which may affect the visual field and appearance, common in neurological or muscular diseases.
Meibomian Gland Orifice Obstruction
Blockage of the meibomian gland orifices, leading to abnormal lipid secretion and potentially causing dry eye symptoms.
Fibrovascular Growth on Cornea Observed (Pterygium)
A wing-shaped pterygium is present on the conjunctiva, which may cause blurred vision or discomfort, requiring regular monitoring or surgical treatment.
Entropion with Trichiasis
Inward turning of the eyelid causes eyelashes to grow inward, potentially irritating the cornea and causing pain or discomfort.
Ectropion with Punctal Eversion
Outward turning of the eyelid causes exposure of the punctum, potentially leading to abnormal tear drainage or dry eye symptoms.
Dendritic Corneal Ulcer
Fluorescein staining reveals a branching, tree-like ulcer on the corneal epithelium, characteristic of herpes simplex virus infection.
Abnormal Meibum Expression
Abnormal secretions from the meibomian glands on the eyelids, which may lead to dry eye symptoms or discomfort.
Lacrimal Sac Reflux
Regurgitation of fluid from the puncta upon compression of the lacrimal sac, which may indicate nasolacrimal duct obstruction or infection.
Decreased distance vision, significantly improved with negative spherical lens correction
Distant objects are blurry, but vision improves significantly with a negative spherical lens; a defining feature of refractive myopia, distinguishing it from hyperopia/presbyopia.
Squinting to see distant objects
The patient squints unconsciously when viewing distant objects to increase depth of field and reduce aberrations, which can subjectively improve clarity slightly.
Poor stereopsis
Limited binocular fusion leads to reduced or absent stereoscopic vision, common in individuals with amblyopia or strabismus, affecting fine motor skills and distance judgment.
Visible strabismus
When one eye fixates on a target, the other eye deviates; can manifest as esotropia, exotropia, or vertical deviation, often accompanied by diplopia or suppression.
Suppression scotoma
To avoid diplopia, the brain actively suppresses the image from one eye, creating a functional scotoma; commonly seen in patients with amblyopia/strabismus.
Scissoring reflex on retinoscopy
During retinoscopy, the red reflex shows a splitting and crossing scissor-like movement, indicating irregular astigmatism, often seen in keratoconus.
Weiss ring observed
A ring-shaped opacity (Weiss ring) is visible anterior to the optic disc, often indicating posterior vitreous detachment; requires vigilance for associated retinal tears.
Retinal neovascularization
Abnormal, fragile blood vessels formed in response to ischemia, prone to hemorrhage and traction; common in proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
Yellow-white choroidal lesions observed
Yellow-white lesions with potentially indistinct borders are seen in the fundus, may be associated with retinal/choroidal reactions, suggesting choroiditis or related diseases.
Active choroidal lesions
Imaging suggests lesions are in an active phase, often accompanied by exudation, fluorescein leakage, or an increase in adjacent vitreous cells.
Vitreous inflammatory cells (+)
Slit-lamp/fundus examination reveals suspended inflammatory cells and opacities in the vitreous cavity, often indicating active posterior uveitis.
Positive RAPD
Swinging flashlight test indicates a relative afferent pupillary defect, commonly seen in unilateral (or asymmetric) optic nerve disease.
Pain on eye movement
Retro-orbital or posterior ocular pain experienced when moving the eyes, often associated with inflammation of the optic nerve and its sheath.
Dyschromatopsia
Decreased color discrimination and saturation perception, often affecting the red-green spectrum, and may be accompanied by reduced contrast sensitivity.
Amblyopia detected
Reduced visual acuity that persists after ruling out organic lesions of the cornea, lens, vitreous, and retina, consistent with the diagnostic criteria for amblyopia.
Retinal microaneurysms
Ophthalmoscopy reveals small, red, dot-like lesions (microaneurysms), mostly in the posterior pole; indicative of mild diabetic retinopathy, typically without neovascularization.
